lines.text: Goodbye, you, Tom Collier.
Goodbye? Until when?
Doomsday, my darling.
You're a free man you know, Tommy, always have been with me, no questions asked, but oh, please, Mexico in June, together, because listen... No, don't look at me. Look in the other way.
[Takes a deep breath]
On the boat coming over, the sweetest small boy, about two, and I got crazy about him and I want one. I want one *badly*. So would you please be good enough to marry me?
[Is startled and stands straight up]

Oh, you always said you wanted to and I wouldn't let you. Well, it isn't terribly serious, not a life sentence, you know, just for a little while if you like. Will be such a dirty trick on him if you didn't.
Behold, the bridegroom cometh. And no oil for my lamp, as usual. A foolish virgin me. Oh, foolish anyway.
I thought for a long time we have been out of page so far as... so far as...
Wanting each other goes?
Well, haven't we?
Speak for yourself, Tom.
You too, Daisy. You first, I think.

Well, it's true that side of it was never so much to us, not in comparison, not... well not after those first crazy months. But I... I thought that was natural. I was even glad. Glad that it was all our needs that held us together. So closely. Not a claim. Never a claim but so closely.

[Holding Cecilia's hands and admiring her]
Oh, Cee darling, what a marvellous object you are.
[They kiss]
Oh, I feel good.
So do I.
Do you?
[Ogling her from head to foot]
I love you, Cee.
Stop it, Tom. You're embarrassing me.
Why?
I feel quite naked.
For all our big talk, we both still belong to the animal kingdom.
There, there, now. Don't worry. Tom will be along any second.
If what I think is true, I hope he never comes along.
What?
Well, I'll, I'll tell you what's in my mind. Heaven knows I don't want it there. That girl he's been living with for the last three years...
Just a minute, sir.
It's alright Owen.
Good Jupiter, it's no secret, is it? Who is she, anyway? What is she?

An extremely nice girl. Hard working. Talented. She, she draws for one of the fashion magazines and very successfully. She left three months ago for her magazine's Paris office for an indefinite stay.
Faith is a beautiful thing.
Tell me, darling, did you really say you'd marry me?
I'm afraid I did.
Oh, heaven help us both. Just this one marriage please. You know I haven't been very good about marriage. I was exposed to a very bad case of it as a baby. We must make a grand go of it.
Oh, we shall. Never you fear.
Well, you-you just do everything I say and it'll be alright.
With pleasure, sir!
Well, Cee, for a long time I've known, known intimately, a girl whose been very important to me.
Yes.

Daisy's done more for me than anyone in this world. She's the best friend I've got. I believe she always will be. I'd hate terribly to lose her. It's-it's been a queer sort of arrangement. Or, no arrangement at all, really. There's been no idea of marriage between us.
I see.
Cee, we've, well we've been everything possible to each other, of course. But,
Yes, Tom.
At the same time, as free as air. I mean, there's never been any feeling of conventional responsibility towards each other, involved in it.
I can understand that.
Can you, Cee? Because, I never could.
Oh, well. I suppose publishers have to hobnob with all sorts of queer people.
Well, you know there's a thing called - legal ethics.
There's a thing called - friendship.
Cee, your eyes are so bright.
Oh, eat you. You're seeing things.
Cee.
Yes, dear.
You know, a little love is no love.
We shouldn't. You know we shouldn't.
But, eh, we seem to be.
All at once, I feel terribly naughty, somehow.
Champagne, the friend of lovers.
On ordinary terms, Tom doesn't seem to have got very far. He's wasted his life from the cradle.
Aaw, it must have been pathetic to see him wasting at three!

I assure you his genius was shown even then. I send him to Harvard, he lasts two years there. I send him to Oxford, he commutes from Paris. I put him into a bank, he... The whole world is at the feet of that boy, the whole world. And all he's ever done is to run from it.
Well, I guess I'd better be barging along, as they say. I, er, I am sure it's getting cold by the minute.
Yes, it's almost cold enough to... You know, I, I think we'd best bring in the brass monkeys tonight, don't you?
Love will conquer all, yes, yes, of course. But, but forgive me a few doubts.
I read the new book you published last week, Tom.
Oh, yes? What-what do you think of it?
Superlative, my dear. I was simply ravished.
If you're ever hard up, though, you know were to come.
That goes both ways.
Red, do you ever think about your future?
I guess where I'll go, it'll be plenty hot.
Job? Oh, the job! Oh, I gave that up last winter. A trifle, eh, shall we say, quixotic of me.
Why do you suppose she asked us out here, anyway? Just to prove we don't belong?
Oh, she isn't a bad sort. You know, I had quite a long talk with her tonight. She seems like a very nice, attractive woman.
Hmm, so did Delilah.
Oh, sweet innocent... I should think you'd know by now, that she was just a promiscuous little - oh well.
You're a strange girl, Cee. You're a pretty cruel one too.
Not at all. In fact, I don't see why Tom and she shouldn't be just as good friends as, well, as you and I are.
Their history is a little different.
Why? Don't you like our history?
What there is of it. A trifle uneventful, don't you think? Or, should we simply call it, lacking in excitement.
I know, the Florentine! A private room at the Florentine.
What's that?
Its a sort of hotel. Run by a woman called Flora Conover.
Sounds wicked.
It used to be the best place in London.
Place? What sort of place?
Twenty guineas.
Twenty guineas?
On the mantle piece.
What are you talking about?
In advance, at that.
Rather expensive, wasn't it?
Well, one went to Flora's to celebrate and the food was good, the waiter discreet, the wine excellent, the lady most artful.
I don't care to hear about it, thank you.
Oh, Cee, my lovely Cee, where are you? What's become of you?
